column2: Grant an Estate to this character. This will give them a monthly revenue and make them more loyal to you.
Grant an Estate to this character. This will give them a monthly revenue and make them more loyal to you.
Consider the size of the Estate that will be granted to §Y[This.GetTitledFirstName]§! (you will also have the opportunity to reconsider, if you wish).\n
As an adult member of the Wuxia faith, it’s time for you to choose which school of martial arts you will pursue in order to reach Enlightenment.
I will choose my father's sect.
I will choose my mother's sect.
I shall let the gods decide my sect.
Your character is currently retired from their lives as a ruler to train in the martial arts.
As a Wuxia practitioner, you can spend a period of time in training and contemplation.
Your month long training has come to an end, you can now return to your normal life.
I shall return to my normal life.

You have spent the last few days training with [new_sect_friend.GetFirstName] Their skills and yours seem to develop better when you challenge each other, and [new_sect_friend.GetHerHis] has asked you if you wish to train together more often.

You were training at the local monastery of your Sect, when suddenly a person entered from the gate. [new_sect_enemy.GetFirstName] claims that your sect is not the true path to Enlightenment, and challenges your Sect to prove otherwise by facing him in honorable duel.
Or we can all show you.
[new_sect_enemy.GetFirstName] lies defeated on the ground. Before falling unconscious and being escorted outside, he swears revenge on you. You might have made an enemy today…

You fall on your knees, defeated by your opponent’s mastery of martial arts. [new_sect_enemy.GetFirstName] roars in triumph, gloating at his success. As they walk away, your fellow Sect members help you up. They offer words of encouragement, but you can tell they are a bit disappointed.
The time spent Training has proven useful. You can feel your body invigorated, and the soreness in your muscles is gone. Under the guide of your Sect, you have stepped further toward Enlightenment.

Your muscles are sore, your back hurts, and training with the traditional weapons of your Sect has left your hands bloody without being any close to mastering them. Even with the help of your Sect, you don’t feel particularly close to Enlightenment.

Your fellow Sect members have expressed their concerns over your diet. They believe you are spending too much time eating, and not enough time contemplating the meaning of your training. “It is not just power we seek, young man. You must abandon mortal desires if you hope to achieve the true goal of our faith.” A Master wisely warns you.

Your refusal to eat has caught the eyes of several fellow Sect members. Together, they come to you and suggest you should try to eat more. “We admire your dedication to fasting, but it is unwise to weaken yourself by doing so. One must find a fine balance, lest they lose their way toward Enlightenment.” A Master warns you.
I will fast as I see fit.

As the dawn shines through the sky, your night of meditation comes to an end. The morning dew has settled on your brows and air, and you feel one with nature, fully connected with the world around you. As a bird settles on your shoulder, you breath, at peace.

The scorching heat of the sun burns on your shirtless body, but you hold steadfast on your goal. Spending the entire day exposed to the elements in this summer day will strengthen your body and mind. With that in mind, you try to hold your meditative state through the hottest part of the day.

The snow settles on your shoulders and head as you take deep breaths to calm your shivering. Shirtless, you feel the icy wind running on your skin, and the melting droplets of snow descend on your face and body, as it grows colder. You try to hold through the night as your skin grows cold.

You are training by yourself on a peaceful incline not far from the temple, when suddenly an old man sits nearby, watching you. As time passes, you can’t help but notice the intensity of his look. Unable to hold your curiosity, you speak. “Can I help you, sir?” You ask, without interrupting the flow of your training. The man smiles. “I’m a wandering traveller, nothing more.” He replies, “Merely pursuing Enlightenment in my own way.”

After a little longer, the man notices your lack of interest. He stands up, bowing. “May your training prove successful, and your mind grow clearer.” He says, before disappearing down the slope. You wonder who he was. In his stride, however, you recognize the fierce stride of a trained warrior. Perhaps he was more than meets the eye…
May you have a safe travel.

“Your own way?” You ask, wary. It’s not rare for members of rival Sects to ambush each other, and in the way the man carries himself you recognize someone with a mastery of Martial Arts. “My own way. I seek to better myself, not through the Sects, but through my own strength. A lonely path, but a rewarding one.”Those words catch your attention. Is there another path, besides the Sects?

He nods, and lets you sit in front of him. He shares his tales of training alone, in the mountains, tide down by nothing. A path of self-reflection and self-discovery, and a path of developing unique styles of martial arts, personal to him. He tells you the tale of the immortals that can reach the very pinnacle of their strength, the Xian, the masters of Qi Cultivation. As he talks, you grow…
Angry at his words against the Sects, enough to stand up and leave.

He continues explaining, and you find yourself fascinated by the tales of great exploits and by the idea of immortality achieved through lonely training. As he continues, you ask. “Would you teach me the way to reach this goal?”He smiles. “It is not for me to teach, it is for you to learn by yourself. Set forth alone and find your path. The way of Xianxia is arduous, but rewarding.”With those words, he stands up, bows, and before you can say anything more sets on his way.
As a Xianxia practitioner, you can spend a period of time in training and contemplation.
You have completed your month of training and have made some small progress on your skills.
You have completed your month of training and have made some progress on your skills.
You have completed your month of training and have made moderate progress on your skills.
You have completed your month of training and have made no progress on your skills while also injuring yourself.
You have completed your month of training and have made some great progress on your skills.
You have completed your month of training and have made massive strides on your skills.
You have completed your month of training and can now be considered a fully fledged duelist, though additional training won't hurt your skills.
Xianxia practitioners follow the respected practice of meditating under a waterfall. You have found a suitable waterfall, and have the chance to follow their example.
The time spent Training has proven useful. You can feel your body invigorated, and the soreness in your muscles is gone. You Qi is growing strong, and you have stepped further toward Enlightenment.

Your muscles are sore, your back hurts, and training with your weapon has left your hands bloody without being any close to mastering them. Even with your Qi reinforced, you don’t feel particularly close to Enlightenment.

As the dawn shines through the sky, your night of meditation comes to an end. The morning dew has settled on your brows and air, and you feel one with nature, fully connected with the world around you. As a bird settles on your shoulder, you breath, at peace.

The scorching heat of the sun burns on your shirtless body, but you hold steadfast on your goal. Spending the entire day exposed to the elements in this summer day will strengthen your body and mind. With that in mind, you try to hold your meditative state through the hottest part of the day.

The snow settles on your shoulders and head as you take deep breaths to calm your shivering. Shirtless, you feel the icy wind running on your skin, and the melting droplets of snow descend on your face and body, as it grows colder. You try to hold through the night as your skin grows cold.

You are training by yourself in a lonely clearing, surrounded by nothing but trees and animals, when suddenly an old man sits nearby, watching you. As time passes, you can’t help but notice the intensity of his gaze. Unable to hold your curiosity, you speak. “Can I help you?” You ask, without interrupting the flow of your training. The man smiles. “I’m a wandering traveler, nothing more.” He replies, “Merely pursuing Enlightenment in my own way.”

After a little longer, the man notices your lack of interest. He stands up, bowing. “May your training prove successful, and your mind grow clearer.” He says, before disappearing down the slope. You wonder who he was. In his stride, however, you recognize the fierce steps of a trained warrior. Perhaps he was more than meets the eye…
May you have a safe travel.

“Your own way?” You ask, wary. It’s not rare for Xianxia practicioners to ambush each other, and in the way the man carries himself you recognize someone with a mastery of Martial Arts. “My own way. I seek to learn from the Grandmasters of far off Sects, to better myself and teach their way to others.”Those words catch your attention. Another path to strength?

He nods, and lets you sit in front of him. He shares his tales of training with others, side by side with fellow apprentices and under the guiding hands of Masters and Grand Masters with knowledge beyond anything he could know. A path toward bettering one another, of developing together rather than alone. He tells you the tale of the Grand Masters that can reach Enlightenment, and pass on the path toward such goals to their successors. As he talks, you grow…
Angry at his words, enough to stand up and leave.

He continues explaining, and you find yourself fascinated by the tales of great exploits and by the idea of learning from others. As he continues, you ask. “Would you teach me the way to reach this goal?” He smiles. “It is not for me to teach, not here in those lonely woods. Set forth and seek out a Master. The way of Wuxia is difficult, but rewarding.” With those words, he stands up, bows, and before you can say anything more sets on his way.

You have trained for a long time, spent years bettering yourself, as your Qi grew and your strength followed. Finally, one day, you feel the Qi of all things swirl around you. The world sits still, and as you let out a shaky breath, it knows a Xian lives, and will live forever.

For too long your physical weakness has stood in the way of your path to become a Xian. It is time to undergo a dangerous training, but a rewarding one. There is a chance you might die, but there is also a chance you might leave behind all your fragilities.

The Shindo faith follow different beliefs compared to others within their group thus they are able attack other Shintoists

The Ardhanarishvara cults worship the god Shiva together with his consort Parvati. Shiva represents the male reality of the universe, whereas Parvati represents the female reality, together representing the inseparability of the male and female principles of God.

The Saraswati cults are primarily devoted to Saraswati, the goddess of knowledge, art, and music. She is one of the physical manifestations of Mahadevi and is worshipped by Buddhists and Jains as well as Hindus.
The cults of the minor devas are devoted to an assortment of less popular regional deities found across eastern India, and village deities called gramadevatas.

The Jagannath cults are primarily devoted to Jagannath, most frequently worshipped as a fierce manifestation of Shiva and the god of annihilation. To Vaishnavists, he is an abstract representation of Vishnu or Krishna and sometimes worshipped as the ninth avatar of Vishnu. The annual Ratha yatra festival is held in Jagannath's honour.

The Uma cults are primarily devoted to Uma, also known as Parvati, the goddess of power, nourishment, and motherhood, and the consort of Shiva. She is one of the physical manifestations of Mahadevi and is considered the lineal progenitor of all other goddesses. She has many manifestations, the most commonly worshipped being Durga and Kali.

Donyi-Polo is the indigenous animistic and shamanic religion of the Tani and other Tibeto-Burman peoples of Arunachal Pradesh and Assam in Northeast India. The name "Donyi-Polo" means "Sun-Moon", and was chosen for the religion in the process of its revitalisation and reformation shortly before the event into a system of decentralised temples that nonetheless uphold a unified canon of their faith.

§Y*§! Can venerate ancestors 
§Y*§! Can gain sympathy with buddhist and indian religions
§Y*§! This religion venerates nature
§Y*§! Is excluded from standard pagan inferiority at conversion
§Y*§! Can Build Cairns in Temple Holdings

The native Gond religion, Koyapunem meaning "the way of nature", was founded by Pari Kupar Lingo. In Gond folk tradition, adherents worship a high god known as Baradeo, whose alternate names are Bhagavan, Kupar Lingo, Badadeo, and Persa Pen. Baradeo oversees activities of lesser gods such as clan and village deities as well as ancestors. Baradeo is respected but he does not receive fervent devotion, which is shown only to clan and village deities, ancestors, and totems. These village deities include Aki Pen, the village guardian and the anwal, the village mother goddess, a similar paradigm to folk traditions of other Dravidian peoples. Before any festival occurs, these two deities are worshipped. Each clan has their own persa pen, meaning "great god". This god is benign at heart but can display violent tendencies.

§Y*§! This religion venerates nature
§Y*§! Rulers can gain Sympathy towards other religious groups
§Y*§! Army morale is determined by Haruspicy
§Y*§! Can choose to become Vegetarian
Salla is respected by the Bhumkas. It can be spent for various favours within the Temples. Like Prestige, it is added to your score on the death of your ruler.

Kirat Mundum, is the animistic folk religion that is indigenous to the Kirati ethnic groups of Nepal, Darjeeling and Sikkim, primarily practiced by Yakkha, Limbu, Sunuwar, Rai, Thami, Jirel, Hayu and Surel peoples in the north-eastern Indian subcontinent. It is a unique blend of shamanism, animism, ancestor worship and Shaivism. the religion primarily centers around the male and female manifestations of the supreme being Tagera Ningwaphuma those being Theba Sammang and Yuma Sammang which will occassionally reincarnate on earth in human. The religion was reformed in the century prior to the event into a series of interconnected but nonetheless independent temples and monastaries which withstood the turmoil of the event well and following the apocalypse spread to become the sole religion of the Kirati peoples once again.

Sanamahi Laining or Meiteism, is an ethnic religion of the Meitei people of Manipur in Northeast India. It is a polytheistic religion that is named after the God Lainingthou Sanamahi, one of the most important deities of the Meitei faith. Sanamahi is the eldest son of the supreme god Yaibirel Sidaba and the supreme goddess Leimarel Sidabi. Traditionally every Meitei household, irrespective of the religion, worships Sanamahi and Leimarel Sidabi. Following the event the faith has become extremely aggressive towards other religions wishing to convert those who forcibly converted their God-King Sanamahi's adherents.

Sarvodaya, meaning "universal uplift" is an Indian post-Event movement that arose after the fall of Indian democracy. Described by contemporary scholars as something between a religion and a philosophy, adherents of Sarvodaya consider themselves the true successors of the Indian state. While their beliefs are still largely Dharmic in nature, considering all Hindu gods valid manifestations of Brahman or Shakti, they are ultimately secular, not encouraging or discouraging any worship among their followers. Sarvodaya adherents worship a wide variety of gods, Hindu or otherwise, but a curiosity in their lands is the notable lack of state-funded temples, with the religion having no formal religious hierarchy and any religious temples being privately upkept. Philosophically, Sarvodaya largely draws inspiration from the teachings of the legendary Mahatma, with an extremely strict adherence to ahimsa and vegetarianism. Additional key sages in Sarvodaya are Vinoba Bhave, Nehru, and Shrimad Rajchandra, among others. Politically, Sarvodaya fiercely advocates for "swaraj" - the concept of self-rule. While some consider this to mean self-rule of countries against foreign powers, the most often interpreted meaning is the self-rule of the populace against the political state both morally and economically. As a result, Sarvodaya realms are often republican and elective in nature, and tyranny is rarely tolerated. Additionally, Sarvodaya adherents are frequent practitioners of satyagraha, the practice of nonviolent resistance. Sarvodaya satyagrahis frequently attempt to achieve positive social changes throughout India to varying levels of success.

As a Japanese Samurai, it is your duty to be active and involved in the affairs of your realm. You may ask your court chaplain to be on the lookout and inform you should there be troubles brewing or even rumours of treasure.
This character is considered scum within the Japanese faiths and cultures for being dishonourable.
This character is considered Admirable within the Japanese faiths and cultures for being honourable.
This character is considered Venerable within the Japanese faiths and cultures for being honourable.
This character is considered Distinguished amongst the Japanese faiths and cultures for being honourable.

As a ruler, it is your duty to be active and involved in the affairs of your realm. You may ask your court chaplain to be on the lookout and inform you should there be troubles brewing or even rumours of treasure.
This character is considered scum within their faith for being dishonourable.
This character is considered Admirable within their faith for being honourable.
This character is considered Venerable within their faith for being honourable.
This character is considered Distinguished within their faith for being honourable.

Your court chaplain informs you of one of your demesne's smaller towns reporting a sharp uptick in wolf attacks, slaughtering many of the villagers' cattle and even attacking one of the farmers. They suggest leading a small hunting party to cull their population. While some would consider this a menial task not fit for a ruler, but there is still glory to be made in doing it.

Your hunting party scours the countryside to cull the wolves who have been praying on the local livestock. Unexpectedly the wolves are far more tenacious and cunning than you expected, perhaps due to surviving previous culling attempts. One particularly nasty wolf has leapt on you and almost dismounted you. While you managed to kill the wolf, it did manage to injure you.

Your hunting party scours the countryside to cull the wolves who have been praying on the local livestock. You manage to cull a majority of the wolf population but a number of them manage to evade your hunting party. While not completely ending the threat of preying wolves, the locals are very grateful.

Your hunting party scours the countryside to cull the wolves who have been praying on the local livestock. You quickly manage to surround the wolf packs and cull them all in a quick manner. After the successful hunt, the grateful locals praise your name as a hero.

Your court chaplain informs you of one of your demesne's smaller towns is reporting a serious increase in banditry, robbing travellers. They suggest leading a small party to find their camp. While some would consider this a menial task not fit for a ruler, but there is still glory to be made in doing it.

You personally set off to the countryside to deal with the emerging bandit threat that's been plaguing the locals. The noise you've been making seems to have roused the bandits, and manage to ambush your expedition, killing several of your men as well as injuring you, you are lucky to have escaped with your life!

You personally set off to the countryside to deal with the emerging bandit threat that's been plaguing the locals. Your plan to catch the bandits by surprise fails to materialize as the bandits seem more prepared than you would have liked. Still, your expedition manages to take several bandit camps, the expedition is called off before the bandit threat could be fully eliminated. The locals are still grateful for your efforts.

You personally set off to the countryside to deal with the emerging bandit threat that's been plaguing the locals. The expedition manages to catch the bandits off guard and quickly routs them. The locals cheer you on as you return gallantly from the expedition, the countryside is now safe from the bandit threat.

During the expedition to end the bandit threat in the countryside, one of the bandit leaders, perhaps seeing which way the wind is blowing has decided to swear allegiance to you, along with his group. Your officers caution you against recruiting such an unscrupulous fellow but his skills may be of use to you.

Your court chaplain informs you of one of your demesne's temples is reporting a serious increase in attacks, they occasionally attack the temple and attempt to burn it down. They suggest leading a small party to find their camp. While some would consider this a menial task not fit for a ruler, but there is still glory to be made in doing it.

You set off to hunt down the temple burners personally. Having heard that you set off to hunt them down, the cunning thieves have set up a trap and managed to kill some of your men, one of them even injuring you. You escape their ambush but you have to call off the pursuit after the thieves escape. To save face, you offer your help in renovating the burnt temple.

You set off to hunt down the temple burners personally. You manage to track them down quickly after arriving to the site of the burnt temple, and manage to kill a good number of them and retrieve a portion of the stolen goods, but the leaders of the thieves manage to escape. You still offer your assistance in renovating the temple much to the locals gratitude.
You set off to hunt down the temple burners personally. You manage to track them down quickly after arriving to the site of the burnt temple, and hunt them down to the man.

You set off to hunt down the temple burners personally. You manage to track them down quickly after arriving to the site of the burnt temple, and hunt them down to the man. Thankful for your effort, as well as your offer to help finance the temple's renovation, a humble and learned priest from the temple offers you their services.

Your court chaplain informs you of one of your barracks has reported the thievery of several horses. Your men suggest leading a small party to find their hideout. While some would consider this a menial task not fit for a ruler, but there is still glory to be made in doing it.

You set off to retrieve the stolen horses and hunt down those who took them. But the thieves ambush you, ironically using the horses you set out to retrieve and kill half of your men. One of them manages to strike you before quickly being dispatched by your bodyguard, you then manage to retreat but you have to call off the expedition.

You set off to retrieve the stolen horses and hunt down those who took them. You manage to find the camp where the horses were kept, but find no sign of the thieves. Proclaiming your expedition a success, you return triumphantly with the horses in tow.

You set off to retrieve the stolen horses and hunt down those who took them. With the help of the locals you manage to track down the thieves camp and quickly cut them down, retrieving the horses unharmed.

You set off to retrieve the stolen horses and hunt down those who took them. With the help of the locals you manage to track down the thieves camp and quickly cut them down, retrieving the horses unharmed. Upon your return, a lone warrior offers their services for you, explaining that he was looking for the stolen horses as well.

Your court chaplain informs you of one of your marchants has reported the thievery of several chests of gold. Your men suggest leading a small party to find their hideout. While some would consider this a menial task not fit for a ruler, but there is still glory to be made in doing it.

You set off to hunt down the thieves who have been disrupting merchant activity in the countryside. Upon arriving at the thieves camp to retrieve the stolen goods, the thieves ambush your men and kill a dozen of them. One of the thieves even attempted to kill you but your life was saved by a bodyguard, but you are still injured.

You set off to hunt down the thieves who have been disrupting merchant activity in the countryside. You manage to track down groups of thieves and retrieve the stolen goods, but upon returning, you realize that some merchants goods are still unaccounted for. Most of the merchants are still quite grateful for your efforts.
You set off to hunt down the thieves who have been disrupting merchant activity in the countryside. You manage to track down the thieves and kill them to the man.

You set off to hunt down the thieves who have been disrupting merchant activity in the countryside. You manage to track down the thieves and kill them to the man. Upon returning, the merchants offer you gifts of gratitude, but one merchant, with a caravan of weapons and all kinds of goods goes above and beyond and offers you his services.

Your court chaplain informs that an enemy spy ring has formed in one of your cities and they're attempting to foment unrest. Your men suggest leading a small party to find their hideout. While some would consider this a menial task not fit for a ruler, but there is still glory to be made in doing it.

The group you sent to kill the spies returns empty handed, they believe the spies were tipped off and evacuated before any of them even set foot in their headquarters. As you were walking near your keep shortly afterwards an assassin attempted to murder you and you were injured.

The group you sent to kill the spies returns and tells you that the spies they managed to kill is below the reported number of spies according to your intelligence, and that they believe that some of the spies managed to escape.
The group you sent to kill the spies returns triumphant, proclaiming that they managed to hunt down all of the spies and that they will no longer disturb the peace in the city.

The group you sent to kill the spies returns triumphant, proclaiming that they managed to hunt down all of the spies and that they will no longer disturb the peace in the city. But more interestingly, the leader of the expedition tells you that they were assisted by one of the spies who turned on the others and offered his services to you instead.
